definitions.definition: to tell somebody what to do, especially in an annoying way
definitions.sensetop: dictate something (to somebody)dictate how, what, etc…/that…

examples.text: They are in no position to **dictate terms** *(= tell other people what to do)*.
What right do they have to dictate how we live our lives?
It was only the king or queen who could dictate policy.
This political stance had been dictated by the Prime Minister.

definitions.definition: to control or influence how something happens

examples.text: When we take our vacations is very much dictated by Greg's work schedule.
It's generally your job that dictates where you live now.
The social conventions of the day dictated that she should remain at home with her parents.
What followed dictated the course of his life.
This is clearly the best choice, unless financial considerations dictate otherwise.
She had to remain indoors for 30 days before the wedding, as custom dictates.

definitions.definition: to say words for somebody else to write down or to be recorded

examples.text: She dictated the letter to her assistant.
OK, you write, and I'll dictate.
Just dictate into the machine—we'll transcribe it later.

wordOrigin: late 16th cent. (in sense (1)): from Latin dictat- ‘dictated’, from the verb dictare.
